Graphical abstract Ni-based catalysts supported on sepiolite were synthesized by different preparation procedures for the production of γ-valerolactone from levulinic acid and its esters (methyl levulinate and ethyl levulinate). The optimal performance was related to the formation of tiny nickel particles. Interestingly, the reaction conditions significantly influence the reactivity of the substrates. The catalytic performance of the optimal Ni/sepiolite catalyst was compared with two catalysts of ruthenium (supported on γ-alumina or sepiolite). In all cases, the production of γ-valerolactone depends on both the substrate employed and the reaction media. Overall, the preferred reaction media using the Ni-catalyst is 2-propanol whereas pressurized hydrogen in water is the best alternative for Ru-catalysts. In both cases, a reasonable stability has been observed after 3 cycles. Finally, the use of metallic Zn in an aqueous medium to provide hydrogen could not be considered as an appropriate option due to the lack of a stable behaviour. Keywords γ-valerolactone Levulinic acid Methyl levulinate Ethyl levulinate Nickel Ruthenium Sepiolite Alumina 1 Introduction The increasing demand of chemicals and liquid fuels and the diminishing amounts of petroleum have made that new carbon sources like lignocellulosic biomass have been investigated to produce value chemical products. Lignocellulosic biomass is the ideal renewable carbon source for replacing fossil fuels [1,2]. The use of lignocellulosic biomass as a carbon source presents many advantages since is abundant, accessible and widely available throughout the world. Using biomass instead of petroleum the negative environmental effects caused by chemical industry can be reduced [2,3]. γ-valerolactone (GVL) is a biomass-derived chemical product that can be used as a fuel component or additive, helping to reduce net carbon emissions. GVL can be also converted into other valuable compounds such as ethyl valerate (suitable as a gasoline additive) a methyl pentanoate (convertible into adipic acid, caprolactam or dimethyl adipate, which are nylon intermediates [4–10]). GVL is a colourless liquid with a low melting point (−31 °C), open cup flash (96 °C) and a high boiling point (207 °C). It is also an environmentally benign solvent and it has good transport and storage properties [11]. GVL can be produced through catalytic hydrogenation of different compounds, being levulinic acid (LA), methyl levulinate (ML) and ethyl levulinate (EL) some of the most studied ones (Fig. 1 ). This hydrogenation catalytic route is one of the key reactions in sustainable biomass conversion. LA, ML and EL can be obtained from cellulose by acid hydrolysis, with hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) and furfural (FF) as intermediates products [12]. LA conversion into GVL has been widely studied, this reaction involving dehydration to angelica lactone and its subsequent reduction or the reduction to 4-hydroxypentanoic acid and further dehydration [13]. Besides, other studies have been carried out using ML and EL as substrate to obtain GVL by hydrogenation catalytic reaction with high conversion rates using different types of catalysts [14–17]. Hydrogenation reactions must be carried out with a hydrogen donor. Then, molecular hydrogen has been employed in many studies due to its good results [14,18–22] although its use presents some disadvantages such as problems in transport and difficult storage. Other hydrogen sources have been investigated, e.g. formic acid (FA) [23,24]. FA can be catalytically decomposed into CO2 and H2, and then, hydrogen is used for the hydrogenation reaction of LA, ML or EL to GVL, this way avoiding the need for an external hydrogen supply. Alcohols have been also used as hydrogen source in the GVL process from LA, ML or EL. Typical alcohols employed are 2-propanol, 2-butanol or isopropyl alcohol [25–29]. These alcohols are used as both solvents and hydrogen donors. In this case, the hydrogenation proceeds via the Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley reaction, presenting a good chemo-selectivity for the carbonyl groups reduction and taking place with moderate/high efficiency if an optimal catalyst is used. Another possibility for the hydrogenation reaction of LA, ML or EL to GVL is using water to produce hydrogen with metallic catalysts. This catalytic route has been explored in a few studies, where Zn is used to produce hydrogen from water for different applications [30–32]. The use of Zn for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL has been reported in few studies and hydrogen was produced from water at low temperatures [30,33,34]. Zn, in this case, does not act as a catalyst but as a reactant, as reacts with water producing H2 and ZnO. Zn + H2O → ZnO + H2 ; ΔH = − 63 kJ/mol (298 K) In a final step, ZnO could be reduced into Zn using solar energy for doing greener process and reducing wastes [35]. There are many studies with homogeneous, heterogeneous catalysts or a mixture of both [36–38]. Noble metals such as ruthenium, palladium, platinum or gold have been used as heterogeneous catalysts due to their high conversion rates and high selectivity into GVL. The most widely used noble metal is ruthenium since it is the one that shows the highest yields [39–44]. However, noble metals are expensive, and their use increases the cost of the process. Because of that, non-noble metals have been tested in GVL production. Thus, nickel, cobalt, iron or zirconium have been tested because are inexpensive, commercially available and catalysts based on them are relatively easy to prepare [17,27,45–50]. Recently, catalysts of silver and cobalt with a core–shell structure was demonstrated to present an outstanding performance [51]. In this work, it was demonstrated that the presence of surface density of Lewis/weak acidic sites favours the hydrogenation step in hydrodeoxygenation reactions. Other non-conventional materials such as zirconium-based metal organic framework have been also studied for the ML transformation into GVL showing promising results [52]. Nickel has been one of the most studied non-noble metals for the GVL production because it is abundant, cheap and reaches good yield to GVL from LA, ML or EL [30,53–57]. For example, a mixture of Fe and Ni supported on active carbon has been successfully used for EL hydrogenation, obtaining 99.3 % yield to GVL at 100 ⁰C for 6 h and 4 MPa H2 [16]. Another study with Raney Ni achieved a GVL yield of 94 % at 120 ⁰C for 1 h using ML as substrate and 2-propanol as solvent and hydrogen donor [28]. In other studies, at lower temperatures, Ni was supported on sepiolite and was used in reactions at 30 ⁰C for 2 h and a yield of 25 % to GVL was obtained with LA as substrate and Zn to produce hydrogen from water [30]. In the catalysis field, the size of the active metal particles is of paramount importance. Tiny crystallites involve more surface active sites and often is related to a higher catalytic activity. In order to improve the metallic catalysts activity (increasing the amount of available sites) and reusability (decreasing the extent of leaching by enhancing the metal-support interaction), metals are supported on different materials to obtain well dispersed and small size nanoparticles [39,42]. The nature of the support is also an important factor governing the catalytic activity because it is crucial for an adequate dispersion and structure of the metal particles on the support [49]. Sepiolite has been used in many studies because it is a very cheap support, which can decrease the production costs. Sepiolite is a type of magnesium hydro-silicate mineral which has two discontinuous tetrahedral silica structure and a major magnesia sheet to form a framework of nano-tunnels. Sepiolite has a large surface area and high porosity due to the inversion of the SiO4 tetrahedral along the Si-O-Si direction. Hydrophilic functional groups can be anchored on the sepiolite surface through silanol groups (Si−OH). These features of sepiolite make it a valuable support [58]. The incorporation of metals on the support is also important because there are different preparation methods and the size of metallic nanoparticles and their dispersion on the support depend on the synthesis method [59]. Wet impregnation method has been the most employed to synthesize catalysts, but other methods have been also studied such as precipitation method, grafting, ion exchange or solid-state ion exchange. Depending on the preparation method, the catalytic activity could be greatly modified. Thus, this paper is focused on the study of a set of Ni metallic catalysts supported on sepiolite for the transformation of LA, ML and EL into GVL using different reactants conditions as hydrogen donors (propanol, pressurized hydrogen in water or water + Zn). Ni catalysts were prepared through four different methods. Then, the conversion obtained with the different substrates was comparatively analysed for establishing which one of the prepared Ni catalysts is the optimal. Furthermore, it has been elucidated whether the ideal substrate for its conversion into γ-valerolactone is the same regardless of the reaction medium or whether, on the contrary, it is highly dependent. On the other hand, although this reaction has been widely studied and it is known that GVL can be obtained with high efficiency from LA, ML and EL, it is hardly known if the optimal catalysts are the same for the different substrates (levulinic acid or its esters). Moreover, it has been reported that these substrates can be transformed into γ-valerolactone using different reaction media, but little is known concerning the adequate selection of the optimal catalyst for each reaction medium. In order to get deeper insight about this point, the catalytic performance of the optimal Ni/sepiolite catalyst has been compared with those of a standard Ru/alumina catalyst and a Ru/sepiolite catalyst for the transformation of LA and its esters. In these cases, hydrogen was supplied i) from the decomposition of water as hydrogen donor using Zn as a reactant, ii) from pressurized molecular hydrogen, and iii) from 2-propanol. In the present article, it is demonstrated unambiguously that the optimal catalyst for the production of γ-valerolactone depends on both the substrate (levulinic acid, methyl levulinate or ethyl levulinate) and the reaction media. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Ni was supported on sepiolite (Sep), which was collected from Toledo (Spain) and provided by Sepiolsa (Azuqueca de Henares, Spain). Sepiolite composition was: sepiolite 97 wt. %, dolomite 1.9 wt. % and other clays 1.1 wt. %. Catalysts were synthesized by different methods, all of them presenting the same theoretical initial concentration of Ni (2 wt. %). The nickel source employed is nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2.6H2O from Sigma–Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA, >98 %. Firstly, a catalyst was synthesized by impregnation method with ethanol and oxalic acid dihydrate (H2C2O4.2H2O also from Sigma–Aldrich) with a molar Ni:oxalic acid ratio of 1:3. Oxalic acid is used to decrease the crystallite size of nickel and nickel oxides, therefore increasing the amount of available nickel sites [30]. Sepiolite was added to the solution and placed in a hotplate at 60 °C under stirring until all the solvent was evaporated. This mixture was dried at 100 °C for 12 h and later calcined at 500 °C in static air for 2 h. Finally, the catalyst was heat-treated in a flow of H2 at 400 °C for 2 h in order to reduce metal oxide precursors. This catalyst was labelled as 2Ni/sep-i. A second nickel-based catalyst was synthesized by thermal decomposition of urea, which decomposes generating CO2 and NH3, thus causing an increase in the pH and therefore the precipitation of Ni species. Urea was added with a urea:sepiolite mass ratio of 1.3:1 in an aqueous solution. Nickel nitrate was added to the mixture and placed in a hotplate at 90 °C under stirring until the decomposition of urea was completed and it was removed when the solvent was evaporated. Then, the wet solid obtained was dried at 100 °C for 12 h, calcined at 500 °C for 2 h in air and reduced in flowing H2 at 400 °C for 2 h. This catalyst was labelled as 2Ni/Sep-u. Precipitation method was used to synthesize a third catalyst. An aqueous solution with the appropriate amount of Ni and sepiolite was prepared and a solution of Na2CO3 (Sigma Aldrich, 99 %) (0.3 M) was added by dropwise, until a pH of 11 was reached. Then, it was stirred for 1 h and was further filtered and washed with distilled water. Then, the wet solid obtained was dried at 100 °C for 12 h, calcined at 500 °C for 2 h in air and reduced in flowing H2 at 400 °C for 2 h. This catalyst was labelled as 2Ni/sep-p. The last catalyst was synthesized mixing sepiolite with a solution of 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) (Sigma-Aldrich, 98 %), using toluene (15 mL) as solvent, in a reflux at 110 °C for 24 h. The solid was filtered after the grafting, washed with toluene and dried at 120 °C for 12 h. The recollected solid was added to an aqueous solution of nickel nitrate and was stirring for 2 h under ambient conditions. After, the mixture was filtered, discarding the presence of Ni in the filtered liquid [59]. Then, the wet solid obtained was dried at 100 °C for 12 h, calcined at 500 °C for 2 h in air and reduced in flowing H2 at 400 °C for 2 h. This catalyst was labelled as 2Ni/sep-a. With the aim of evaluating the activity of these catalysts compared to that displayed by noble metal-derived catalysts, two Ru-based catalysts were synthesized by impregnation method with ethanol and using sepiolite or alumina as support. The appropriate amount of Ruthenium acetylacetonate (Sigma-Aldrich, 97 %) was mixed with 40 mL of ethanol and then 2 g of the support (sepiolite SBET = 242 m2 g−1 or γ-Al2O3 from Sued Chemie, SBET = 187 m2 g−1) were added to the mixture. The mixture was placed in a hotplate stirrer at 60 °C under stirring until the solvent was evaporated. These catalysts were dried at 60 °C for 12 h, calcined at 500 °C for 2 h and finally heat-treated in a flow of H2 at 400 °C for 2 h. The final Ru concentration was 2 wt. % and the catalysts were labelled as 2Ru/sep and 2Ru/alum. 2.2 Characterization techniques Catalysts were analysed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) in order to know the crystalline phases of the catalysts and to check if there were oxidized or reduced nickel. The equipment used was an Enraf Nonius FR590 sealed tube diffractometer (Bruker, Delft, The Netherlands) equipped with a monochromatic Cu Kα1 source (30 mA and 40 kV). The catalysts structure and morphology were analysed by High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). A field emission gun TECNAI G2 F20 microscope (FEI Company, Hillsboro, OR, USA) at 200 kV and a JEM 3000 F microscope (JEOL, Tokyo, Japan, 300 kV) were employed. The EM equipment was also used for energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED). Catalyst samples were sonicated for 20 min in absolute ethanol and deposited on a holey carbon fil, supported on a copper grid. Later, the copper grid was dried. The average size of the nickel particles was calculated by TEM photographs and particle-size histograms were constructed by measuring 80–100 particles, depending on the catalyst. Catalysts were tested to N2 adsorption at 196 ⁰C, using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 apparatus (Norcross, GA, USA). First, catalysts were degassed at 150 ⁰C before the analysis. Adsorbed volume at a relative pressure of 0.99 was used to calculate total pore volumes. A multipoint Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) specific surface area (SBET) was determined through the relative pressure range from 0.05 to 0.25. The pore size distribution was analysed using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method by analysing the adsorption branch of the N2 adsorption isotherms. NH3-TPD was measured by using a Micromeritics Pulse Chemisorb 2700 instrument equipped with a TCD. The catalysts (0.2 g) were degassed under an Ar flow at 500 °C for 6 h followed by saturation at 150 °C using a 30 cm3 STP/min flow of 5% v/v NH3 in Ar. The gas mixture was then switched back to Ar and the sample was purged at 125 °C for 30 min. NH3-TPD profiles were subsequently recorded under 30 cm3 STP/min He flow, from 50 °C to 600 °C using a heating rate of 5 °C/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were made on a Kratos Axis ultra DLD photoelectron spectrometer using a non-monochromatized Mg Kα X-ray source (hν =1253.6 eV). Analyser pass energy of 50 eV was used for survey scans and 20 eV for detailed scans. Binding energies are referenced to the C1s peak from adventitious carbonaceous contamination, assumed to have a binding energy of 284.8 eV. XPS data were analysed using CasaXPS software. All the peaks of the corrected spectra were fitted with either asymmetric or Gaussian–Lorentzian shape functions to peak fit the data. Iterations were performed using the Marquardt method and following those restrictions previously optimised by Morgan [60]. Relative standard deviations were always lower than 1.5 %. 2.3 Catalytic test and analyses The catalytic conversion of levulinic acid, methyl levulinate or ethyl levulinate into GVL was carried out in a 13 mL stainless steel autoclave at 180 °C. In a typical experiment, 175 mg of catalyst and 1.24 mmol of substrate were used. 1) In the reactions with alcohol as hydrogen source, 3.5 g of 2-propanol (Sigma-Aldrich, 99 %) were mixed with the catalyst and the substrate. 2) If the reaction was carried out with molecular hydrogen, 3.5 g of water were added as a solvent together with the catalyst and the substrate. The reaction was carried out at 30 bar of hydrogen pressure (initial pressure). 3) If Zn was used as the hydrogen generator from water, 171.6 mg of Zn and 3.5 g of water were well mixed and placed in the reactor together with the substrate and catalyst. Controls were realized without Zn or catalyst and adding only Zn with substrate and water. In all cases, the reactor was purged with nitrogen in order to minimize the metal oxidation before reaction. Then, the reactor was sealed and introduced in a silicon bath and stirred at 200 rpm for 2 h at the desired temperature (180 °C). Selected experiments were done at different times to compare the influence of reaction time on the GVL production. After the reaction, the reactor was immediately cooled in an ice-bath to stop the reaction. Finally, the mixture was filtered with an appropriate membrane to obtain the products in order to be analysed. The analysis of the products was undertaken as in [61]. Samples were identified by gas chromatography, using the GC instrument Hewlett Packard 5890 (Palo Alto, California, USA), equipped with an Agilent HP-1 column (30 m ×0.32 mm ×0.25 μm). The detector employed was a FID detector working at 240 °C, and an injection port, working at 220 °C. In a typical run for samples with LA and ML as substrates, the temperature program was: i) 35 °C isothermal for 6 min, (ii) from 35 to 230 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C min−1, and (ii) isothermal at 230 °C for 26 min. On the other hand, GC analyses of the experiments using EL as substrate were as follows i) 35 °C isothermal for 30 min, (ii) from 35 to 230 °C with a heating rate of 1.5 °C min−1, and (ii) isothermal at 230 °C for 26 min. Other minority reaction products were identified using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GV_MS MSD-7890A, Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA). 3 Results 3.1 Nickel supported on sepiolite catalysts 3.1.1 Characterization of the samples Catalysts of nickel supported on sepiolite have been prepared using different preparation procedures: i) impregnation using oxalic acid, ii) deposition-precipitation, iii) precipitation with urea and iv) through the APTES method. Overall, in all the catalysts Ni is present in the metallic state. However, the nickel particles present different mean particle size and distribution depending on the procedure, as will be shown later. Table 1 shows some physicochemical characteristics of the catalysts synthesized. As it can be observed, the actual Ni concentrations in the samples slightly differs from the nominal one for the 2Ni/sep-p and 2Ni/Sep-a catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the Ni samples prepared with the different methods, before (A) and after (B) the reduction steps. The XRD patterns of both the precursors and the final catalysts show the typical reflections of sepiolite. Therefore, the synthesis methods and the thermal reduction apparently did not affect the sepiolite structure since no changes between catalysts and sepiolite XRD pattern were observed. Moreover, a low intensity peak of NiO phase can be observed in the precursor (before reduction) of 2Ni/sep-i but not in the other samples. Significantly, peaks of either metallic nickel or nickel oxide were not observed in the final catalysts. This suggests the small size of the Ni nanoparticles probably as a consequence of the great dispersion of nickel on the support. HRTEM was used to determine the nature of the nickel phases present in the catalysts and locate and measure the Ni particles size on the sepiolite support. Then, the catalysts prepared by different methods (2Ni/sep-i, 2Ni/sep-p, 2Ni/sep-u and 2Ni/sep-a) were comparatively analysed. Fig. 3 shows representative images and Fig. 4 shows the corresponding particle size distributions for all these samples. The morphology of sepiolite fibres with diameters in the 5−20 nm range and lengths from 50 nm to several μm can be clearly observed in all cases. Additionally, in the 2Ni/sep-a catalyst a portion of the sepiolite fibres (ca. 30 %) have been broken presenting a cotton-like shape. The objective of using different preparation methods was to form tiny nickel particles highly dispersed over the sepiolite support. In all cases metallic Ni nanoparticles were detected, as indicated by the observed periodical contrasts of 0.20 nm in the TEM images, which were assigned to (111) interplanar distances of cubic Ni (see inset of Fig. 3b). We would like to point out that their ferromagnetic response was observed as the catalysts could be moved by approaching a permanent magnet. The obtained Ni nanoparticles are smaller in particle size compared to previously reported in similar Ni-clay supported catalysts [55]. The catalyst prepared by impregnation presents spherical nickel particles with sizes mainly between 2 and 4 nm, although particles of up to 8 nm have been detected (Fig. 4). However, in the catalyst prepared by precipitation most of the Ni nanoparticles (ca. 66 %) are smaller than 2 nm. It must be indicated that the low concentration of Ni observed in this sample could be linked to the fact that the precipitation method involves a filtering process, likely decreasing the actual concentration of nanoparticles in the final catalyst. This TEM observation agrees with the chemical analysis of the sample (by ICP), which indicates a lower amount of Ni (1.3 wt.%) if compared with that prepared by impregnation (2.0 wt.%). In the case of the sample prepared in presence of urea an appreciable percentage of larger nanoparticles (up to 6 nm) has been observed, but those with an average size of 2 nm are predominant. Finally, in the catalyst prepared by the APTES method different trends were observed depending on the matrix. As mentioned above, this catalyst presents both sepiolite fibres and a more aggregated cotton-like structure. Thus, on the sepiolite fibres a large proportion of tiny Ni particles were detected whereas larger agglomerations were observed on the cotton-like part of the sample. Textural properties of Ni catalysts were determined by N2 absorption-desorption (Table 1) and Fig. S1 shows the isotherm patterns. All these catalysts display a similar adsorption-desorption isotherm typical of mesoporous materials (type IV). The addition of nickel has meant a decrease of the surface area in the 15–30 % range depending on the preparation method. The pore distribution (Fig. S1b) shows, as in the sepiolite support, the presence of the peak at ca. 3.9 nm, suggesting that the mesopores have not been completely blocked. 3.1.2 Catalytic results Catalytic production of γ-valerolactone from levulinic acid (LA), methyl levulinate (ML) or ethyl levulinate (EL) was studied at 180 °C in an autoclave using the differently prepared Ni catalysts supported on sepiolite. Initially, Ni/sepiolite catalysts were tested using 2-propanol as both reaction medium and hydrogen donor. In this case the GVL production is scarce using LA as a substrate regardless of the Ni-catalyst employed, being the predominant reaction product isopropyl levulinate (IPL). However, if ML or EL are used as substrates the formation of GVL is notorious. For both, ML and EL, the catalyst prepared by precipitation obtained the highest GVL production, being the resultant catalytic activity of the different Ni-based catalysts as follows: 2Ni/sep-p > 2Ni/sep-i > 2Ni/sep-a > 2Ni/sep-u. If the formation of GVL from ML or EL is compared, the highest yield was obtained from EL for all the catalysts. Fig. 5 shows the possible mechanism of the catalytic transformation of ML or EL to γ-valerolactone using 2-propanol as both reaction solvent and hydrogen donor. The mechanism for the GVL formation from EL or ML is very similar, involving a two-stage reaction. Firstly, the formation of the alkylhydroxypentanoate (AHP) and, secondly, the cyclization and loss of either methanol or ethanol to yield GVL. Significantly, the yields obtained using the ethylic ester are remarkably higher since 90.3 % of GVL is obtained after 2 h at 180 °C with the 2Ni/sep-p whilst 33.5 % GL yield is attained from ML. As the conversion and detection of the hydroxypentanoate are higher from the ethylic ester, the first step (Fig. 5) must be faster starting from EL than from ML, whereas the second step seems to be the rate-determining step in both cases. We must indicate that, after 4 h on-line, the selectivity to the AHP intermediate drastically decreases, simultaneously increasing the selectivity to GVL, compared to the 2h-experiment. Overall, after 4 h on-line, EL conversion exceeded 99 % with a yield to GVL of 97 % (Table 2 ). Characterization results indicate that the preparation method highly influences the particle size. Then, the most active catalyst prepared by precipitation showed the lowest mean Ni particle size, with ca. 66 % of the particles being smaller than 2 nm. In the catalysts prepared by impregnation (2Ni/sep-i) or with urea (2Ni/sep-u), more than 70 % of the particles are smaller than 4 nm with a moderate proportion of particles bigger than 4 nm. Regarding the 2Ni/sep-a sample two different morphologies for the support were observed (Fig. 3d): a majority of sepiolite fibres with small Ni particles (around 2 nm) on their surface and a minority of more aggregated structure with large Ni particles (over 6 nm). Therefore, an inverse correlation can be observed between the Ni particle size and the catalytic activity (Fig. S2). The effect of the Ni particle size is highly important because the most active catalyst is that with the lowest Ni-loading, so that the differences in the reactivity per active site is even higher. The Ni/sepiolite catalyst synthesized by precipitation was also tested using pressurized hydrogen. It was demonstrated that this is not an appropriate option to achieve high productions of GVL. In fact, the GVL yield did not exceed 5% after 2 h, regardless of the substrate employed (Table 3 ). Another way of transforming LA or its esters into GVL could be using water as a reaction medium and Zn as a reactant in order to produce hydrogen as a result of the oxidation of Zn to ZnO (Zn + H2O → ZnO + H2). Table 4 shows the catalytic results obtained with Ni/sepiolite catalyst prepared by precipitation. Conversely to the use of pressurized hydrogen, the assistance of Zn led to high GVL yields. Using LA as a substrate a hydrogenation and a dehydration steps are required. The catalyst prepared by precipitation achieved the highest yield to GVL, exceeding 90 % (90.6 % yield) with very high selectivity (> 99 %). As previously shown in Fig. 5, the synthesis of valerolactone from ML requires a two stage reaction, involving the initial decomposition into LA and methanol and subsequently LA hydrogenation/dehydration to yield GVL. Results of the conversion of ML into GVL at 180 °C shows that the ML conversion exceeds 99 %, most of that being GVL and LA. Catalytic results with EL as a substrate on the Ni catalysts and adding Zn were also undertaken (Table 4). Similarly, the synthesis of GVL from EL needs an initial decomposition into LA and ethanol followed by LA hydrogenation/dehydration to GVL. As shown in Table 4, EL conversion exceeded 90 % (mainly producing LA and GVL) but the yield to GVL was lower than 18 %. We would like to point out that blank runs without Ni-catalyst but with metallic Zn were also undertaken. Using LA as a substrate LA conversion reached 35 % with selectivity to GVL of ca. 98 %. Additionally, ML conversion was lower (16.3 %), being the selectivity to GVL very low (5.7 %). Fig. 6 compares the distinct behaviour of Ni/Sep-p catalyst depending on the substrate and the reaction media. Interestingly, the reaction conditions highly influence the reactivity of the substrates. Then, the highest γ-valerolactone yield from LA was obtained using water and Zn (LA > ML > EL) whilst it was obtained with EL using 2-propanol as hydrogen source (EL > ML > LA). Significantly, the formation of GVL using pressurized hydrogen was low for all the substrates. It is noteworthy that yields to GVL close to 98 % are obtained from EL and LA using Zn/water and 2-propanol as hydrogen donors, respectively, after 4 h. The different catalytic performance could be related to the promotion of different reaction mechanisms depending on the reaction media. Using water and Zn, ML and EL are transformed by hydrolysis into LA, which is further hydrogenated into GVL (Fig. 7 ). Then, an additional catalytic step compared to the direct LA transformation is required. Accordingly, LA to GVL transformation occurs with higher GVL formation from LA than from its esters. Interestingly, the GVL formation increases with the time on line whereas the levulinic acid formation decreases. This confirms that the transformation of the esters into GVL goes through the formation of LA by a dealkylation step, in which methanol (from ML) or ethanol (from EL) are formed (see Fig. 7). These alcohols have been detected and quantified by GC-FID analysis. Then, the first step (hydrolysis, releasing methanol or ethanol) presents a fast reaction rate whereas the hydrogenation/dehydration takes place at slower rate. However, when LA is fed, the reaction rate for GVL formation is much faster. Reaction rates for GVL formation have been calculated at low reaction times (ca. 15 min) showing that reaction rate from LA is ca. 3 times that from ML and ca. 6 times that from EL. Then, the hydrolysis step of the alkyl levulinates, which is strongly favoured, delays the subsequent hydrogenation/dehydration, and this is more remarkable in the case of ethyl levulinate. However, if 2-propanol is used (Fig. 5), GVL is the major product from ML and EL with methyl 4-hydroxypentanoate or ethyl 4-hydroxypentanoate being the intermediates of the reaction, respectively [62,63]. These steps, especially in the case of EL, take place fast. However, using LA the formation of a highly stable compound (isopropyl levulinate) as an intermediate is remarkable, slowing down the IPL to GVL step. In order to achieve higher GVL yields longer reaction times, higher reaction temperatures or even increasing the metal loading are required [64]. In water with the addition of Zn the production of GVL is easier using LA as a substrate. Trying to obtain higher conversion of ML into GVL, new experiments were undertaken changing the amount of both the added catalyst (2Ni/Sep-p) and Zn in the reaction, without modifying the other reaction conditions (Table S1). The yield to GVL is low if Ni-catalyst or Zn reactant are used in control experiments. However, if used together, the yield to GVL highly increases (from 1 % to 37–89 %), which demonstrates the complementary role of both. The best results were obtained when using the highest amounts of both the catalyst and Zn. Then, if 300 mg of 2Ni/Sep-p and 300 mg of Zn were used, 89 % of yield to GVL was obtained after 2 h, which is a better result than using 175 mg of 2Ni/Sep-p and 171.6 mg of Zn after 6 h at the same temperature. Then, the productivity of lactone per mass of catalyst increases when the amount of both the Ni-catalyst and Zn increases. This could be due to an enhanced hydrogen production that allows the Ni-sites to act with higher reaction rate (if the Zn amount increases and the amount of Ni-catalyst keeps constant) or to the presence of more available active Ni-sites that can transform faster the substrates (if the amount of Ni-catalyst increases and the amount of Zn keeps constant). This increase in the amount of added catalyst and Zn could reduce the reaction time to obtain a high yield to GVL using ML as a substrate, making the process to be cheaper. 3.2 Comparative study between Nickel on sepiolite catalysts vs Ruthenium catalysts Ruthenium is considered as the most efficient metal for the transformation of LA into GVL [65–67]. Then, we found interesting to compare the performance of the optimal nickel catalyst, i.e. 2Ni/sep-p, with that of two Ru catalysts. As a support for ruthenium we have selected the standard support (γ-alumina, with acidic characteristics) as well as that used with the nickel catalysts (sepiolite) (Table 5 ). XRD of Ru on sepiolite as well as some representative TEM images are shown in Fig. 8 . Fig. S3 shows the XRD patterns of fresh and used Ru-catalysts, showing as a unique ruthenium containing phase metallic Ru. XPS measurements were performed to obtain information on the oxidation state of the Ru and Ni species on the surface of the catalysts. The study was undertaken over the Ru-catalysts (Ru/sep and Ru/Al) as well as two representative Ni/sep catalysts (Ni/sep-i and Ni/sep-p). Thus, the Ru 3d, Ru 3p and Ni2p core levels spectra were analysed. For the Ru-based samples characteristic asymmetric peaks related to metallic Ru were clearly observed for both Ru 3d and Ru 3p orbitals, see Fig. 9 a. Binding energy values were in line with those reported for metallic Ru [60], as shown in Table S2. It should be remarked that there was no significant contribution of any Ru oxidised species, as expected for samples treated in a hydrogen atmosphere at 400 °C. Conversely, contribution of both metallic and oxidised species was observed in the case of the Ni samples analysed (those prepared by impregnation or precipitation), despite these samples were also treated in hydrogen. This result is not surpring since similar findings were previously reported by Anderson et al. [67]. Accordingly, both spectra show two peaks in the region corresponding to Ni 2p3/2 photoelectrons. The most intense asymmetric broad peak appears at BE at ca. 854 eV, whilst a broad symmetric peak due to shake-up phenomena appears located at ca. 6 eV in the high BE side. For the first unresolved peak, two contributions can be differentiated corresponding to one symmetric peak for Ni2+ at ca. 855 eV and another asymmetric peak for Ni° at ca. 852.5, respectively [68]. As postulated by Anderson et al. [67], the ratio between the integrated peak area for metallic nickel and the total nickel peak area could be related to the degree of reduction at the surface, being these values 27 % and 41 % for Ni/sep-i and Ni/sep-p samples, respectively. The higher degree of reduction could be observed for the Ni-sep-p sample, which can be also associated to the higher activity of this sample. The no detection of NiO in the TEM study could be related to the structure of the Ni-containing particles (for example a core-shell structure with the outer part of the particle being totally reduced). In the comparative catalytic study, we also used different hydrogen sources (i) in-situ hydrogen from Zn oxidation in water, ii) 2-propanol and iii) molecular hydrogen) as well as three substrates (levulinic acid, methyl levulinate and ethyl levulinate). These results are summarized in Table 6 . Overall, we can state that none of the catalysts tested can be considered as the “best one” for the transformation of LA and alkyl levulinates into GVL, since different catalytic results have been obtained depending on both the reaction media and the substrate employed (Fig. 10 ). In the case of 2-propanol being used as a hydrogen source, the GVL production is scarce using LA regardless of the catalyst employed because of the low activity and the remarkable formation of isopropyl levulinate. However, if ML and EL are used as substrates the formation of the lactone is important. For both ML and EL, the catalyst with Ni obtained the highest GVL production: Ni/sep-p > Ru/Al ≈ Ru/sep. Therefore, Ni-sites have shown to be more efficient than Ru-sites for the Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley reaction. Unexpectedly, Ni-catalyst presents for any substrate very low production of GVL when pressurized hydrogen is added. In contrast, Ru-catalysts, especially that on alumina, presents remarkable yields to γ-valerolactone, which are close to 100 % for all the substrates just after 4 h or less. If both supports (alumina and sepiolite) are compared for Ru it can be observed that Ru/sepiolite presents the best performance, the GVL yield exceeding 96 % after 2 h whereas the GVL yield of that on alumina is 85.7 %. Interestingly, after 2.5 h using Ru/sepiolite catalyst almost all the substrate is converted into GVL (99.7 %). The choice of the support seems to play a role as sepiolite is preferable with LA whereas with ML and EL the alumina catalyst yields more GVL. Ru catalysts supported on alumina and sepiolite were characterized by HRTEM in order to detect possible differences that could affect the catalytic behaviour. Interestingly, in both Ru-catalysts the only presence of metallic Ru was detected, the mean ruthenium particle size and the size distribution being similar for both supports (Table 5). Therefore, the different catalytic performance must be related to the characteristics of the support rather than to the ruthenium sites where acidity properties of the supports could exert an important role. In fact, it has been demonstrated that the amount and strength of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites highly influences both the catalytic activity and the selectivity to GVL [45,55,69]. For example, in the transformation of LA to GVL the first step is the dehydration for which acidic sites are required whereas in the hydrogenation step the metallic sites are the active ones. In the case of the dehydration step Lewis sites have been reported to be more efficient than Brønsted acidic sites [43]. Moreover, strong Brønsted acidity seem to be deleterious for achieving high GVL selectivity as these sites tend to decompose GVL. Additionally, it has been also reported that the presence of weak surface Lewis acidic sites seems to favour the LA to GVL reaction by favouring the hydrogenation step [51]. Fig. 11 shows the TPD of adsorbed ammonia over the catalysts tested. It was observed that both supports show a similar NH3-TPD profile with two main features [70]. The first feature with desorption from 150−300 °C to 300−400 °C is an indication of weak and medium adsorption sites that could be associated with surface hydroxyl groups and marginal Brønsted acidic sites on the supports, respectively. The second feature with desorption temperature ranging from 400 to 600 °C could be attributed to strong acidic sites, which could be associated with surface Lewis acidic sites. All these acidic sites, surface hydroxyl groups, Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites were more relevant for the alumina support, leading to a total acidity (700.2 μmolNH3/g) significantly higher than that found for sepiolite (499.8 μmolNH3/g). Similar features were found for the Ru supported catalysts although a comparable increase in the amount of weak acid sites can be observed for each catalyst. Then, although basic materials can also catalyse the hydrolysis of esters, it can be concluded that acid supports favour the hydrolysis of the alkyl levulinates into levulinic acid [71], as this step must proceed faster in Ru/alumina than in Ru/sepiolite and probably this is related to the higher GVL formation when esters are used as substrates with alumina support. Finally, in the transformation of LA in water and Zn the most efficient catalyst resulted to be the Ni/sepiolite catalyst although for all 3 catalysts the formation of GVL was remarkable (Table 6). The use of Zn and water with Ni-catalyst leads after 2 h to the massive formation of GVL from LA (ca. 91 % yield) and moderated from the esters (38 and 18 %, from ML and EL, respectively). This result is not easy to explain as in the case of co-feeding Zn, the main role of Zn is the production of hydrogen through its reaction with water and we have observed that Ni sites on sepiolite are not active for the GVL formation using molecular H2 as a donor. In order to bring some light into this behaviour, we characterized the used Ni-catalyst after being used with Zn. It could be observed that, after use, Zn had either oxidized into ZnO or reacted with the sepiolite of the support forming Zn-silicate (Fig. 12 ), probing that Ni-catalyst is highly unstable under these experimental conditions. Then, we picked up the used sample (Zn + Ni/sepiolite) which had reacted to form Zn-silicate after LA transformation, and dried overnight in a furnace at 150 °C. The typical amount of catalyst was employed using the standard pressurized hydrogen conditions (30 bar) in the hydrogenation of LA. Surprisingly, this new phase led to the formation of a relatively high GVL yield (44 %) after 2 h on-line (Table 6). Then, it seems that whilst Ni-sites in Ni/sep-p catalyst are poorly active in the presence of molecular hydrogen towards GVL formation, this reaction can be successfully accomplished over Zn-silicate species (or the Ni, sepiolite, Zn-sepiolite mixture). We want to mention that the Ru/alumina catalyst used in the present article was selected as it has been previously reported that equivalent catalysts are highly efficient in the transformation of levulinic acid into valerolactone. Then, using a catalyst synthesized similarly to that of the present article containing the same Ru-loading (2 wt.% Ru/Al2O3) at a reaction temperature of 130 °C and 4 MPa of molecular hydrogen in water reaches a yield to GVL of 99 % [72]. These conditions are not so different compared to ours (130 vs 180 °C and 4 MPa vs 3 MPa). Another Ru/alumina catalyst [73] with higher Ru loading (5 wt.%) at 140 °C and 5 MPa of molecular hydrogen yielded 98 % GVL after 5 h of reaction. A similar catalyst with 5 wt.%Ru [74] using an ethanolic media and adding hydrogen (1.2 MPa) achieved a yield to GVL of 32 % at 130 °C, which increased until 76 % employing an ethanol + water mixture. A remarkable result is that achieved by Van Nguyen et al. [75] in which a yield to GVL of 88 % was achieved in water at low temperature (60 °C) and pressure (1 atm of H2) using a 3.2 % wt Ru catalyst supported on Al2O3 3.2.1 General remarks Overall, Ni-catalyst is the preferred option if using 2-propanol whereas Ru-catalysts behave remarkably better with pressurized hydrogen. The higher efficiency using 2-propanol of Ni is not straightforward to explain. However, this can be related to the higher selectivity towards hydrogen of nickel sites compared to those of ruthenium in the decomposition of 2-propanol [76]. Similarly, in previous works related to catalysed hydrogen production from propanol, Ru-based catalysts presented low hydrogen production as the undesired methanation reaction was favoured [77]. Additionally, Ni nanoparticles have been reported to be slightly more efficient than similar Ru nanoparticles in the dehydrogenation of 2-propanol, and it was ascribed to the different electronic structure of the metals (the reaction rates for dehydrogenation was linked to the differences in the position of the d-band centre with respect to the Fermi energy) [78]. Thus, the intervention of the catalysts in the dehydrogenation reaction of 2-propanol could be a relevant factor in the observed response. To understand the different behaviour of the Ni and Ru catalysts, it has to be taken into account that the reaction with 2-propanol takes place in the absence of water and the reaction using molecular H2 as hydrogen source uses water as solvent. In the literature, there are several investigations that show an improved behaviour of Ru catalysts when water is present in the medium. Then, supported Ru samples were reported to be the most efficient catalysts to obtain a rapid and selective conversion of carbonyl functionalities into the corresponding alcohols [79]. Two mechanisms could be considered. In one hand, co-adsorbed water molecules decrease the energy barriers, leading to an easier hydrogenation of carbonyl groups by dissociated hydrogen. On the other hand, the dissociation of water increases the surface concentration in hydrogen atoms, thus facilitating the hydrogenation process. In both cases, it is related with the oxophilicity of the metal and, according to that, Ru (0.4) presents higher values than Ni (0.2) [80]. Specifically for the LA to GVL reaction, Michel et al. [81] demonstrated using DFT calculations that the catalytic activity of Ru sites is highly sensitive to the media and this is due to the presence of a H-bonded water molecule, which drastically lowers the energetic span of the reaction and, therefore, enhances the catalytic activity in the selective transformation of levulinic acid. Then, oxophilic metals are favoured if working in water whereas others, supposedly more reactive, such as Pt or Pd, are not favoured [82]. As a summary, Table 7 shows the preferred option regarding substrate and reaction media. The use of Zn in an aqueous medium does not seem to be an appropriate option due to the lack of a stable performance as metallic Zn either oxidizes into ZnO or reacts with sepiolite. However, the use of pressurized hydrogen in water or 2-propanol are appropriate alternatives if the nature of the catalyst is optimized. Finally, we want to mention that stability tests were conducted using Ru/sepiolite with pressurized hydrogen in LA transformation and using Ni/sep-p with 2-propanol in EL transformation. After 3 cycles a rather stable behaviour with low deactivation was observed in both cases (Fig. S4). However, after 10 cycles moderate/high deactivation was observed with Ru/sep catalyst. 4 Conclusions Ni-based catalysts supported on sepiolite were synthesized by different preparation procedures for the production of γ-valerolactone from different biomass derived compounds such as levulinic acid, methyl levulinate and ethyl levulinate. The most efficient catalyst was that prepared by a simple precipitation method. This catalyst delivered the highest yields to γ-valerolactone regardless of the substrate used. The optimal performance achieved by the catalyst prepared by precipitation was related to the formation of nickel particles with small size. Interestingly, the reaction conditions highly influence the reactivity of the substrates. Then, using water and Zn as hydrogen donor, the highest γ-valerolactone yield was obtained from levulinic acid (levulinic acid > methyl levulinate > ethyl levulinate) whilst using 2-propanol as hydrogen donor, the highest yield was obtained with levulinates (ethyl levulinate > methyl levulinate > levulinic acid). The different reaction mechanism explains this distinct catalytic behaviour. Finally, the use of pressurized hydrogen (30 bar) demonstrated to be a poor alternative (yields lower than 5 %). Ni/sepiolite catalyst synthesized by precipitation was used to compare its catalytic performance with two benchmark catalysts of ruthenium (supported on γ-alumina or sepiolite). For this comparative study, different hydrogen sources with levulinic acid and its esters, methyl levulinate and ethyl levulinate were employed. Overall, it was observed that none of these catalysts can be considered as optimal for production of γ-valerolactone since this reaction depends on both the substrate employed and the reaction media. Using pressurized hydrogen ruthenium supported on sepiolite led to the highest lactone yield from levulinic acid. However, ruthenium on alumina presented the highest GVL formation from both methyl and ethyl levulinate. The hydrolysis step seems to be favoured in supports like alumina which is more acid than the sepiolite support. With pressurized hydrogen, the γ-valerolactone formation using the Ni-catalyst was very low for all the substrates. Then, the capacity of Ni-sites for the hydrogenation using molecular hydrogen is very low. Significantly, the lack of stability of the Ni-catalyst during the reaction with Zn, with the subsequent formation of a Zn-silicate phase, promotes the formation of γ-valerolactone. In fact, this Zn-silicate phase has been shown as reasonably active for γ-valerolactone production using pressurized hydrogen in the transformation of levulinic acid. The use of propanol led to negligible formations of GVL from levulinic acid regardless of the catalyst employed. However, using the esters the production of the lactone was remarkable, the Ni-catalyst achieving the highest yields to GVL, higher than with ruthenium. The different mechanism of the reaction and the distinct characteristics of nickel and ruthenium sites could explain this behaviour. Overall, the preferred reaction media using Ni-catalyst is 2-propanol whereas pressurized hydrogen is the best alternative for Ru-catalysts. In both cases, a reasonable stability after 3 cycles has been observed. Finally, we want to note that the use of Zn in an aqueous medium is not an appropriate option due to the lack of a stable behaviour since metallic Zn either oxidizes into ZnO or reacts with the sepiolite support. coredata.dc:description: Ni-based catalysts supported on sepiolite were synthesized by different preparation procedures for the production of γ-valerolactone from levulinic acid and its esters (methyl levulinate and ethyl levulinate). The optimal performance was related to the formation of tiny nickel particles. Interestingly, the reaction conditions significantly influence the reactivity of the substrates. The catalytic performance of the optimal Ni/sepiolite catalyst was compared with two catalysts of ruthenium (supported on γ-alumina or sepiolite). In all cases, the production of γ-valerolactone depends on both the substrate employed and the reaction media. Overall, the preferred reaction media using the Ni-catalyst is 2-propanol whereas pressurized hydrogen in water is the best alternative for Ru-catalysts. In both cases, a reasonable stability has been observed after 3 cycles. Finally, the use of metallic Zn in an aqueous medium to provide hydrogen could not be considered as an appropriate option due to the lack of a stable behaviour.
coredata.dc:title: γ-valerolactone from levulinic acid and its esters: Substrate and reaction media determine the optimal catalyst
